instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> will not fully boot
threads.message:
This one came to me not powering on at all. There was no obvious liquid damage, but I found burned <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>. So I changed <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> and the board powered on with chime. After that I installed the board back to case and once I connected the charger to an assembled laptop, <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> burned again and left a burned hole in the board, so it was a bit tricky to replace it again (this time with <CAPACITOR>C8186</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R8186</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D8184</DIODE> and <RESISTOR>R8184</RESISTOR> as they were burned by <CHIP>U8030</CHIP>). Also I found the original reason of this issue - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> was shorted through microphone connector(J6601), because the microphone itself suffered a TINY liquid damage. With new microphone and once again repaired <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> area it turned on, but it does not fully boot. 
Once it should display login screen, it freezes with distorted image (see attached photo). It will do that with known good original SSD with Mojave installation, and also with Mojave/High Sierra/Sierra USB installers. However it can fully boot to Windows 10. I suspect this is a bad CPU issue? Or maybe some important line burned in different layer of board under <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> (there was a hole through at least 3 or 4 layers I think). 
I would probably already thrash this board, but it's a 16GB one, so I'm already giving it more time than I should :))
Also it does not power on with just charger connected (without battery), but I think this already happened to me on other 2015 Pro's and they were otherwise OK, so that may be normal? However <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is acting strange I think. It's at 12.54V with only the charger connected (turned off, as it does not turn on without battery), but once I connect the battery and reconnect the charger to power it on, the voltage slowly raises up to 13V in a few minutes, or immediately if I disconnect the battery and leave it on with charger only. Other lines are stable.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.86V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.06V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.36V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5.15V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> will not fully boot
threads.message:
Looks like RAM, or CPU issue.
However start flashing new BIOS, with clean ME.
